advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World, October 1983<br><br> Here are some answers:<br><font color="#666666"> "The BBC Microcomputers are the limousines of home computers. The graphics are probably the best' of any machine in this class. You are paying for Ii smart machine which would not disgrace the home of a professional."<br> <i>Video World., Feb. '83.</i><br><br> "Its design has given the BBC Micro an unrivalled potential for business, educational and serious home applications. It has been equipped to function as the heart of a system which can be expanded 10 suit its owner's need?"<br> <i>Which Micro & Software Review, Feb. '81</i><br><br> "The most attractive and exciting feature of the BBC Microcomputer is its enormous potential for expansion which will allow a higly expansive system to be built-up?"<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "They (the graphics) are tremendously exciting, and they are one of the features that make this machine stand out head and shoulders above everything else that is available in the market place at this time"<br> <i>Educalional Computing, May '82</i><br><br> "It is expandable and has a powerful BASIC. It has superb sound and graphics, the software is readily available and the price is righ"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Hampshire.</i><br><br> "The basics are easy to follow. My wife has developed a program for teaching our daughter French vocabulary. Our daughter uses it mainly for games and simple programming"<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Co. Durham.</i><br><br> "It is a very powerful computer, My husband has written his own data base. I have been writing programs and programming games. Even the children have written small programs."<br> <i>BBC Micro owner from Devon.</i><br><br> "No other computer can offer such ease of use when dealing with complex sound effects."<br> <i>Which Micro, June '82.</i><br><br> "It isn't often a journalist can sit down to write about a computer with the certain knowledge that he has never seen a nicer machine."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, Dec. '82</i> "It has got huge potential. Besides playing the games, the whole family are learning basic programming."<br> <i>A BBC Micro owner from Staffordshire.</i><br><br> "Everything possible seems to have been done to ensure that this is not a 'dead end' machine.."<br> <i>Personal Computer World, July '82.</i></font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SCARY...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you believe it?! She is learning how to play flute (mini flute?) with her TO7... The father seems to be a kind of lunatic...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 64 BITS IN 1983?</strong></font><br><blockquote>After the optimistic 36 Mhz. speed, here is the 64 bits processing power... with 8 bits/Z80 cards. Here also, the 64 bits 'power' is obtained by putting eight 8 bits cards together in the case.<br> Not a very honest way to sell a computer that is no more than a classic S-100 / Z80 based system with some multi-user capabilities.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual floppy drive version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IBM T-SHIRT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing: an era comes to the end" <br><br> "The Sirius era begins"</blockquote>

computer.cpu: NEC PD9002 (compatible with Z80 and V30)
computer.description:
There were 2 product lines in NEC personal computers. PC-98xx (16bit) series for business, and PC-8xxx (8bit) series for home-entertainment.
The PC-88VA 2 was a PC-8xxxx series machine but also had V30 complatible mode, called V3 mode (the NEC V30 cpu was upper compatible with the Intel 8086). Thus, tough it was designed for home entertainment, the PC-88 VA /2 could be used for businesses. PC-88VA /2 was one of the highest performance machine in 1987. Especially, its graphic features were remarkable.
However, this machine was unfortunate. NEC released the PC-98DO system in 1989, a PC-98xx series system but but which could also run PC-88xx software. (PC-88VA was a 8bit machine and had a 16-bit mode. PC-98DO was a 16bit machine and had a 8bit mode. It was strange marketing decision...). At this point, PC-88VA /2 became an orphan. It's life ran out by his own mother.
Thanks to Nomura, Hisayuki for these info.
Info badly needed!
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with separated keypad and arrow keys
computer.name: PC-88 VA 2
computer.ports: FDD Interface 5'' 2DD/2HD/2TD (9.3MBytes), HDD Interface (SASI .. same as PC-9801), RS232c, Mouse, Printer, Expansion Bus (C-BUS .. same as PC-9801)
computer.sound: YAMAHA YM-2608 (6 FM Channels, 3 SSG Channels, ADPCM)
